'''Claro Abánades López''' (12 August 1879 – 16 December 1973) was a Spanish journalist, publisher, historian and a [[Carlist]] activist. His career of a journalist lasted over 70 years (1897–1969), though he is rather known as author of studies on history of [[La Alcarria|Alcarria]] and as editor of monumental multi-volume series of [[Juan Vázquez de Mella]] works.
==Family and youth== [[File:Molina de Aragon2.jpg|thumbnail|left|[[Molina de Aragón]]]] Claro Abánades López was born to a [[working class]] family from tierra alcarreña, a natural region covering mostly what is now the [[Guadalajara Province|Guadalajara province]]. His father, [[Pedro Abánades Jiménez]] (1847–1907), was a construction contractor.<ref>“master de obras”, ''La Torre de Aragón'' 15.01.07, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/pdf.raw?query=parent%3A0004276617+type%3Apress%2Fpage&name=La+Torre+de+Arag%C3%B3n.+15-1-1907%2C+no.+5 here]</ref> Little is known about his mother, Antonia López del Rey.<ref>she was born in [[Anchuela del Pedregal]] to Mauricio López and María del Rey, see Claro Abánades' certificate of birth, available [http://postimg.org/image/s5e73e2dz/ here]</ref> The couple had 5 children, Claro born as the second oldest son; all were raised in a profoundly Catholic ambience. He was first educated in the local [[Molina de Aragón|molinese]] Colegio de Santa Clara, a primary school ran by the [[Poor Clares]] order, later to join [[Colegio Molines de los Padres Escolapios]] (Escuelas Pias), a prestigious provincial secondary education establishment; it is there he gained the bachelor title.<ref>Juan Pablo Calero Delso, ''Claro Abánades López'', [in:] ''Diccionario Biográfico de la Guadalajara Contemporánea'' online, 29.12.13, available [http://bioguada.blogspot.com/2013/12/claro-Abánades-lopez.html here]</ref>
Claro intended to pursue law in [[Madrid]], but financial standing of his parents did not allow regular studies; in 1899 he entered Facultad de Derecho of [[:es:Universidad de Madrid|Universidad Central]] (later to become [[Universidad Complutense]]) as an unenrolled student.<ref>Calero Delso 2013</ref> Having graduated at an unspecified date he went on studying philosophy and letters, obtaining diploma in Sección de Historia in 1906.<ref>and later “doctorado” in philosophy in 1906, Gonzalo Díaz Díaz, ''Hombres y documentos de la filosofía española'', vol. 1, Madrid 2003, {{ISBN|9788400081454}}, pp. 27-28</ref> Some time afterwards he became a Doctor in both disciplines,<ref>Calero Delso 2013, Tomas Gismera Velasco, ''Claro Abánades Lopez'', [in:] ''Biografias de gentes de Guadalajara'' 13.12.2013, available [http://gentesdeguadalajara.blogspot.com/2013/12/claro-Abánades-lopez.html here]</ref> in the Spanish education system of the time the title which enabled him to teach in primary or secondary schools.
Claro Abánades married Natalia Arpa, originating from [[Torrijos, Spain|Torrijos]] in the [[Toledo province]]. They initially lived in Molina de Aragón; in 1907 the family moved to Madrid, settling at calle Jesús del Valle in the university quarter.<ref>Calero Delso 2013</ref> Claro was employed as professor at [[Colegio de la Concepción (Madrid)|Colegio de la Concepción]], a prestigious education institution for the privileged and the wealthy. The college remained his primary workplace for unspecified time; in the early 1930s he was already reported as headmaster of another Madrid secondary school, [[Colegio San Ildefonso (Madrid)|Colegio San Ildefonso]], offering a complete Catholic curriculum from kindergarten to bachillerato,<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 30.09.33, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000516103&page=5 here]</ref> involved in education activities as late as in the early 1940s.<ref>in 1943 he was Director Técn. de la Sección de Bachillerato del Colegio de Terciarias Franciscanas de la Divina Pastora de Madrid, Claro Abánades López, ''La Madre Mogas: Bosquejo de una vida santa'', Madrid 1943, front page, see [http://sibhilla.uab.cat/cgi-bin/wxis.exe/iah/scripts/?IsisScript=iah.xis&lang=es&base=fons&nextAction=lnk&exprSearch=ABÁNADES%20LOPEZ,%20CLARO&indexSearch=AU_ here]</ref> The couple had 3 children: Claro Pedro, Mariano and María de los Angeles. The older son, born already in Molina, worked as a journalist;<ref>''Acción. Diario de Teruel y su provincia'', 10.04.34, available [http://bibliotecavirtual.aragon.es/bva/i18n/catalogo_imagenes/grupo.cmd?path=3702753 here]</ref> the younger one became a professor at another secondary school in Madrid.<ref>Juan Manuel Orozco, Don Mariano y la natación sincronizada, [in:] Colegia Infanta Maria Teresa service, available [https://historiasdelinfanta.wordpress.com/profesores/1977-don-mariano-y-la-natacion-sincronizada/ here]; he graduated in 1926, see ''ABC'' 02.10.26, available [http://hemeroteca.lavanguardia.com/preview/1926/10/02/pagina-18/33253989/pdf.html here] and was later very well remembered by his pupils, see huerfanosinfanta service, available [http://huerfanosinfanta.blogspot.com/2012/04/el-eterno-director.html here]</ref>
==Career== [[File:BNN.81.2.JPG|thumbnail|160px|left|''La Torre de Aragón'']] Abánades started his journalist career in 1897,<ref>in 1897 in the local ''La Cronica de Guadalajara'' he published a series of articles titled ''Geografia descriptiva del Señorio de Molina'', Calero Delso 2013</ref> gradually commencing co-operation with many provincial periodicals regardless of their political outlook.<ref>like a republican ''El Molinés'', a liberal ''La Crónica'', a Catholic ''Flores y Abejas'' and many others, though contributing most frequently to ''La Ilustración Diocesana Seguntina'', the first periodical he joined as member of the editorial board, Calero Delso 2013</ref> His contributions ranged from history to politics, literature and customs; touring the province he also kept sending local correspondence.<ref>at one point he had to flee one of the locations, [[Maranchón]], whose inhabitants found his correspondence on the town, published in ''La Crónica'', offending, Calero Delso 2013</ref> In 1906 he co-founded<ref>Angel Monterde Navarro</ref> a petty new journal, ''La Torre de Aragón'';<ref>an 8-page weekly edited from his house at Calle del Chorro, Calero Delso 2013</ref> though not defined politically,<ref>the authors defined themselves as “católicos sinceros” holding the banner of “patria y honor’, ''La Torre de Aragón'' entry at ''emerotecadigital'' service, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/details.vm?lang=es&q=id:0004276416 here]</ref> it pursued a [[Social Catholicism|social-Catholic]] line.<ref>e.g. promoting the campaign to set up Cajas Rurales in the comarca, Calero Delso 2013</ref> Following differences with his partner<ref>the periodical ceased to exist in 1907, ''La Torre de Aragón'' entry at ''Hemerotecadigital'' service</ref> in 1908 he launched an own weekly, ''El Vigia de la Torre''.<ref>though managed together with a local Carlist entrepreneur Clodoaldo Mielgo Castel, Calero Delso 2013</ref> It assumed more militant tone, claiming to have been the unique genuinely Catholic periodical in the province.<ref>and having been allegedly published “con la aprobación y censura ecclesiástica”, Calero Delso 2013</ref> One work described it as Catholic, though formatted along the [[Integrism (Spain)|Integrist]] pattern;<ref>Calero Delso 2013</ref> another one claims that both weeklies revealed a clear Carlist leaning.<ref>Juan Pablo Calero Delso, ''Los curas trabucaires. Iglesia y carlismo en Guadalajara (1868–1876)'', [in:] ''Iglesia y religiosidad en España: historia y archivos : actas de las V Jornadas de Castilla-La Mancha sobre investigación en archivos'', Guadalajara 2001-2, {{ISBN|8493165859}}, p. 375. Once he moved to the capital, Abánades was gradually losing control over ''El Vigia'', which he ceased to support some time afterwards</ref>
In 1910–1914 in Madrid Abánades three times unsuccessfully attempted to launch a local weekly of the Carlist youth: ''Juventud Tradicionalista'',<ref>as a private enterprise, Calero Delso 2013, Gismera Velasco 2013</ref> ''El Combate''<ref>official weekly of the Carlist youth organisation; only one number was issued, [[:es:José Navarro Cabanes|José Navarro Cabanes]], ''Apuntes bibliográficos de la prensa carlista'', Valencia 1917, pp. 276-7</ref> and ''El Cruzado''.<ref>Navarro Cabanes 1917, pp. 280-1</ref> His career in full-blown national newspaper commenced in 1914, when he was invited to contribute to ''[[:es:El Correo Español|El Correo Español]]'',<ref>Gismera Velasco 2013</ref> the official Carlist daily.<ref>in terms of circulation it was laggining behind most popular national newspapers, but enjoyed some sort of prestige as having been in print for 28 years already</ref> Becoming member of its [[editorial board]],<ref>''Revista general de enseñanza y bellas artes'' 01.04.16, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0003993682&page=6 here]</ref> in 1919 Abánades left ''El Correo'' during the [[Mellismo|Mellista]] breakup in the party. The same year he became editor-in-chief of ''[[El Pensamiento Español]]'',<ref>Gismera Velasco 2013</ref> a journal intended to be the piecemouth of the new Mellist party, and kept managing the paper until it ceased to exist in 1923.<ref>Calero Delso 2013</ref>
During the dictatorship Abánades co-operated with a vast array of dailies, be it national ones like ''[[El Día (Spanish daily of 1920s)|El Día]]'' and ''[[:es:La Nación (España)|La Nación]]''<ref>Calero Delso 2013</ref> or local ones, like the [[Gipuzkoa]]n ''[[:es:La Constancia (1897-1936)|La Constancia]]''<ref>''La Constancia'' 30.11.23, available [http://liburutegidigitala.donostiakultura.com/Liburutegiak/download.php?fich=LA+CONSTANCIA%2F1923%2F11%2F30%2F0001.pdf&path=PDF here]</ref> or the Toledan ''El Castellano'',<ref>''El Castellano'' 06.12.22</ref> contributing also to weeklies like ''[[La Ilustración Española y Americana]]'' or ''Le Touriste'' and unsuccessfully renewing attempts to manage own periodicals.<ref>''La Tribuna'' and ''Orden'', Calero Delso 2013</ref> During the Republic he contributed initially to ''[[:es:La Correspondencia Militar|La Correspondencia Militar]]'', in 1932 emerging as its top comentator,<ref>''La Correspondencia Militar'' 20.01.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002276594&page=1 here]</ref> though starting 1933 he switched mostly to ''[[El Siglo Futuro]]'', formally entering its editorial board.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 29.11.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000566308&page=6 here]</ref> He kept publishing also in other Catholic papers, be it local dailies like Navarrese ''[[:es:Diario de Navarra|Diario de Navarra]]'' and even Canarian ''Gaceta de Tenerife''<ref>''Gaceta de Tenerife'' 08.03.35, available [http://h3.bbtk.ull.es/pandora/cgi-bin/Pandora.exe?fn=commandselect;query=id:0003604198;command=download_pdf;tampon=La%20Gaceta%20de%20Tenerife%20(Santa%20Cruz%20de%20Tenerife)%2008/03/1935.%20P%C3%A1gina%201;nombre_pdf=La%20Gaceta%20de%20Tenerife-08.03.1935-pagina%20001 here]</ref> or weeklies like ''[[:es:La Hormiga de Oro|La Hormiga de oro]]''.<ref>''La Hormiga de Oro'' 25.08.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0012119484&page=4 here]</ref> He is not known to have published in two leading national newspapers, the monarchist ''[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]]'' and the Catholic ''[[El Debate]]''. [[File:Insignia of the Commander Grades of the Civil Order of Alfonso X, the Wise.svg|thumbnail|180px|[[Civil Order of Alfonso X, the Wise|Order of Alfonso X]]]] After the [[Spanish Civil War|Civil War]] Abánades was active mostly in [[Prensa Asociata]], the agency he formed part of already before the war and where he remained during the early [[Francoist]] years.<ref>Calero Delso 2013</ref> He also briefly managed an unidentified periodical named “Lúmen”<ref>Calero Delso 2013</ref> and collaborated with a number of other titles,<ref>e.g. in 1963 with ''Nueva Alcarria'' promoting tourism in the area, ''ABC'' 14.02.63, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1963/02/14/043.html here]</ref> above all with ''[[:es:El Alcázar (España)|El Alcázar]]'',<ref>''ABC'' 03.10.43, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1943/10/03/030.html here]</ref> one of key dailies in the [[Falangist]] propaganda machinery.<ref>Calero Delso 2013, though he does not appear as engaged until at least 1948, see Jordi Rodriguez Virgili, ''La cooperativa del diario “El Alcázar”'', [in:] ''Historia y comunicación social'' 5 (2000), pp. 171-187</ref> In the 1940s he became one of the seniors of the Spanish press corps; in 1947, 50 years after commencing his newspaper career, he was awarded the [[order of Alfonso X the Wise]] as “veterano periodista”<ref>''ABC'' 22.04.47, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1947/04/22/005.html here]</ref> and was later named Periodista de Honor by [[:es:Asociación de la Prensa de Madrid|Asociación de la Prensa de Madrid]],<ref>Gismera Velasco 2013</ref> becoming its oldest member.<ref>''ABC'' 18.07.75, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1975/07/18/025.html here]</ref> His latest newspaper piece identified comes from 1969.<ref>Claro Abánades, ''Mella, cantor der Catolicismo'', [in:] ''Portavoz del Circulo Vazquez de Mella'' 3 (1969), p. 10, available [http://ddd.uab.cat/pub/ppc/VM/VM_a1969m8-9n3.pdf here]</ref>
==Journalist profile== [[File:BNN.81.21.JPG|thumbnail|160px|left|''[[:es:La Correspondencia Militar|Correspondencia Militar]]'']] Apart from privately owned, small and ephemeral newspapers, Abánades was heading a major periodical only during his 1919–1923 tenure at ''El Pensamiento Español''; he is also known as forming part of editorial board of ''El Correo Español'' and ''El Siglo Futuro''. None of the sources consulted claims he headed a section or held jobs in middle management editorial structures; in case of the remaining 30-odd titles he seems to have contributed as a correspondent. Though his juvenile pieces covered a wide range of topics, later on Abánades specialised in three areas.<ref>apart from purely editorial work and unsigned pieces; none of the sources consulted provides any information on his would-be pen-names</ref> He supplied weeklies and in some cases dailies with articles focusing on history of Spain and [[Castile (historical region)|Castile]] in particular, often a byproduct of his own research.<ref>see e.g. ''La Hormiga de Oro'' 25.08.32</ref> As [[editor-in-chief]] of ''El Pensamiento Español'' he took part in ongoing political debates, advocating political cause of the Mellistas; later on, during the 1920s and especially the 1930s, this thread was transformed as writings on history and doctrine of [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalism]],<ref>see e.g. ''El Siglo Futuro'' 29.01.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000535941&page=1 here] </ref> usually formatted as more or less direct homages to [[Juan Vázquez de Mella|Vazquez de Mella]].<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 08.08.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000514005&page=3 here] or ''El Siglo Futuro'' 26.02.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000522128&page=1 here]</ref> However, he made his name mostly as foreign affairs comentator.<ref>even fairly distant ones, like the Chinese-Japanese war, see ''La Correspondencia Militar'' 02.02.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002276860&page=1 here]</ref>
His writings, usually medium-size essays of some 500 words, followed major events; their author aimed to inform the readers about international background of specific developments, their logic and implications. Some of them appear questionable; his piece on the [[Greek revolution of 1922]] seems to confuse cause and effect.<ref>''El Castellano'' 06.12.22, available [http://biblioteca2.uclm.es/biblioteca/CECLM/ARTREVISTAS/Toledo/Castellano/Pdf/4017.pdf here]</ref> Most turned out to be quite accurate, like his 1923 prediction that having won the war [[France]] found itself isolated and was not in position to safeguard status quo negotiated in [[Versailles Treaty|Versailles]],<ref>''La Constancia'' 30.11.23</ref> or his 1932 analysis denouncing European collective security systems as unstable and forecasting the advent of power-based politics.<ref>''La Correspondencia Militar'' 20.01.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002276594&page=1&search=Abánades&lang=es%20or%20http://biblioteca2.uclm.es/biblioteca/CECLM/ARTREVISTAS/Toledo/Castellano/Pdf/4017.pdf here]</ref> Most of Abánades’ comments were plagued by political bias, especially by his anti-[[Republicanism|Republican]] and anti-[[British Empire|British]] views.<ref>by no means atypical for Spanish Right, Carlism and other groups, see [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9TCN56ZUSD0 here]. For review of popular approaches to warring parties during the First World War see Cristina Barreiro Gordillo, ''España y la Gran Guerra a través de la prensa'', [in:] ''Aportes'' 84 (1/2014), pp. 161-182</ref> He was the first to note that the [[Greek Republic (1924-1935)|Greek Republic]] would end up in trouble<ref>''El Castellano'' 06.12.22</ref> and the first to speculate how developments in [[Ireland]] or in [[India]] would work to London’s disadvantage.<ref>''La Correspondencia Militar'' 24.02.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002277408&page=4 here]</ref> [[File:ESF 18920201.JPG|thumbnail|160px|''[[El Siglo Futuro]]'']] Abánades’ vision of European political developments in the 1930s was derived from his germanophile<ref>as late as 1923 he appeared in Asociación Nacional Alemana de Empleados do Comercio, ''El Sol'' 18.01.23, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/pdf.raw?query=id:0000266782&lang=es&log=00000000-00000-00001/ here]; he was rewarded with the German Hoher Orden vom Schwarzen Adler, Calero Delso 2013</ref> and conservative outlook. Sympathetic towards the [[Central Powers]] during the First World War, he considered Versailles treaty responsible for long-lasting crisis in international relations. Before [[Hitler]]’s ascension to power he noted that [[Nazi Party|his party]] was “admirably organized on the national basis“ and hoped that ruled by the Rightist alliance, [[Germany]] would be an example to follow when it comes to confronting “communists, anarchists and those who support them with money, namely the Jews and their branch, the freemasonry”.<ref>“el bloque derechista aleimán nos da la pauta a seguir para oponer en la Europa occidental nuevas fuerzas contra las cuales se estrellen las propagandas de comunistas, anarquistas, y las de los que las sostienen con su dinero y sus alientos, que no son otros que los judíos, y su rama filial, la masonería”, ''La Correspondencia Militar'' 23.03.32, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002277809&page=1 here]</ref> Following the assassination of [[Dolfuss]] he shifted his sympathy to the [[Belgian]] [[Rexist Party|Rexists]]<ref>who proposed to do away with "el régimen liberal caduco y estéril" in defense of religion and family; [[Leon Degrelle]] was applauded as "un caudillo joven y valeroso" who will help the Catholic idea to triumph across Europe, Javier Ugarte Telleria, ''En l’esprit des années trente europeo: la actitud del Diario de Navarra y Garcilaso en la primavera de 1936'', [in:] ''Principe de Viana'' 209 (1996), p. 651</ref> and in particular to the [[Italian Fascism|Italian Fascists]]. Always demonstrating respect and esteem for [[Benito Mussolini]],<ref>in the 1920s he was impressed by Italian fascism and kept endorsing it in his publications, also in a paradoxically titled “Mussolini no quiere ser un dictator”, Calero Delso 2013</ref> he titled his 1936 commentary on [[Second Italo-Ethiopian War|Abyssinian war]] “Italia tiene su Imperio”, the headline with a highly nostalgic tone in Spain;<ref>according to Abánades, in Italy the „men of action” prevailed over „men of politics”, Ugarte Telleria 1996, p. 650</ref> he did not miss the opportunity to declare the British the true losers of the conflict.<ref>Ugarte Telleria 1996, 650</ref>
==Author== [[File:Ventosa (Guadalajara) Sant Virgen de la Hoz 2 0 2 FS 9569.png|thumbnail|left|[[:es:Santuario de la Virgen de la Hoz|Virgen de la Hoz sanctuary]]]] Apart from his work as a journalist Abánades was active also as a writer. He published a number of books and booklets; he wrote some of them himself, some were co-authored and in some cases he edited writings produced by the others. His work falls chiefly into 3 areas: drama, history and Carlism, the last two at times hardly distinguishable.
His original contribution consists mostly of historical works related to the Alcarra region. The first to be mentioned is ''El Señorío de Molina. Estudio histórico geográfico'', monumental 6-volume study which has never been published;<ref>and remains in the municipal Molina archives, ''ABC'' 22.12.73, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1973/12/22/049.html here]</ref> its scaled-down versions were ''La Ciudad de Molina'' (1952), ''El Real Señorío Molinés. Compendio de su historia'' (1966), ''Diego Sánchez Portocarrero'' (1966) and ''Tierra molinesa. Breve estudio geográfico de sus pueblo'' (1969), leaving also other related unedited studies in the archive.<ref>''La Casa Comunidad de Villa y Tierra'', ''Geografia histórica de los pueblos del Real Señorio'', ''Hijos ilustres de la comarca molinesa'' and ''El Cabildo Eclesiastico de Molina'', Antonio Herrera Casado, ''Molina de Aragón: veinte siglos de historia'', Guadalajara 2000, {{ISBN|9788495179425}}, pp. 87-8</ref> Somewhat different focus is at work at ''La Reina del Señorío'' (1929), the work dedicated to sanctuary of [[:es:Santuario de la Virgen de la Hoz|Virgen de la Hoz]], the works on local history completed by ''El alcazar de Molina: la Fábrica de Artillería de Corduente'' (1963).<ref>José N. Alcalá-Zamora, ''Altos hornos y poder naval en la España de la edad moderna'', Madrid 1999, {{ISBN|9788489512238}}, p. 129, Emilio Benedicto Gimeno, José Antonio Mateos Royo, ''La minería aragonesa en la cordillera ibérica durante los siglos XVI y XVII'', Zaragoza 2013, {{ISBN|9788415770053}}, p. 281</ref> Among a number of historical publications unrelated to Guadalajara province,<ref>''Una excursión a Toledo'' (1907), ''Guadalalete y Covadonga'' (1911), ''Hernán Cortés y la conquista de Méjico'' (1923), ''Avanzada de Castilla'' (1936), and ''La Madre Mogas. Bosquejo de una vida santa'' (1943), Díaz Díaz 2003, pp. 27-28</ref> ''Apuntes, para una Historia, del Colegio de Madrid de Doctores y Licenciados en Ciencias y Letras'' (1949)<ref>''ABC'' 12.02.50, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1950/02/12/044.html here]</ref> provides valuable insight into the history of Madrid educational structures.<ref>see e.g. Javier Peralta, ''Representación matemática en el Colegio de Doctores y Licenciados de Madrid (1899 - 1949)'', [in:] ''Avances de Investigación en Educación Matemática'' 85 (2004), pp. 87</ref> Finally, other historical studies remain in manuscript.<ref>Like ''La Madre Humildad. Biografía de la Madre Serra'', ''Fundadora y Fundación. Biografía de Sor Joaquina López Alcázar'', ''Geografía especial de España'', ''Historia de la civilización española'', ''Historia de la literatura latina'' and ''La existencia real de Pedro Crespo'', see ''virgendelahoz'' service, available [http://virgendelahoz.com/Primera%20parte.htm here]</ref> In recognition of his merits, Abánades was nominated Cronista Oficial and Hijo Predilecto of Molina de Aragón.<ref>Calero Delso 2013, Gismera Velasco 2013</ref> [[Image:Zumalacarregui portrait.png|thumb|160px|right|[[Zumalacárregui]]]] Abánades’ contribution to Carlist literature is probably mostly about his monumental, 31-volume edition of all works of Vazquez de Mella, published in the 1930s<ref>1.'' Selección de Elocuencia e Historia'', 2. ''Ideario''. T. I., 3. ''Ideario''. T. II., 4. ''Ideario''. T. III., 5. ''La persecución religiosa y la Iglesia, independiente del Estado ateo'', 6. ''Discursos parlamentarios''. T. I., 7. ''Discursos parlamentarios''. T. II., 8. ''Discursos parlamentarios''. T. III, 9. ''Discursos parlamentarios''. T. IV., 10. ''Discursos parlamentarios''. T. V., 11. ''Discursos parlamentarios''. T. VI, 12. ''Dogmas nacionales''., 13. ''Política general''. T. I., 14. ''Política general''. T. II, 15. ''Política tradicionalista'' T. I., 16. ''Política tradicionalista''. T. II., 17. ''Crítica''. T. I., 18. ''Crítica'' T. II., 19. ''Filosofía. Teología. Apologética''. T. I., 20. ''Flosofía. Teología. Apologética''. T. II., 21. ''Filosofía. Teología. Apologética''. T. III., 22. ''Filosofía. Teología. Apologética''. T. IV., 23. ''Temas internacionales''., 24. ''Temas sociales''. T. I., 25. ''Temas sociales''. T. II., 26. ''Regionalismo''. T. I., 27. ''Regionalismo''. T. II., 28. ''El pensamiento de Mella''., 29. ''Juicios sobre Mella''., 30. ''Índice cronológico y temático''., 31. ''Vázquez de Mella y la educación nacional''.</ref> and supplemented by own synthetic attempt, ''Doctrina tradicionalista de las obras de Mella'' (1935). Works retaining historical profile are ''La Casa de los Tradicionalistas'' (1918), ''Leyendas y Tradiciones'' (1923), ''Carlos V de España'' (1935), ''Centenario del Tradicionalismo Español'' (1935), ''Carlos VI, Conde de Montemolín'' (1936), ''Carlos VII, Duque de Madrid'' (1936), ''Balmes'' (1936), ''Las predicciones de Mella'' (1940) and ''Dinastia insobornable'' (1962).<ref>Gismera Velasco 2013</ref> Finally, publications intended as current political leaflets are ''Filosofía de la vida'' (1911), ''El peligro de España'' (1914), ''El año germanófilo'' (1915), ''La legitimidad'' and ''¿Quién es el Rey, de derecho en España?'' (1916), ''La resurrección de Don Quijote'' (1921), ''Un verano, por el Mediodía de Francia'' (1928) and ''Gibraltar y Tánger'' (1929).
The last and the least-known part of Abánades’ works is this related to the theatre. Probably in the very early years of the 20th century he wrote ''La mano de una madre'', a drama played at various opportunities at Teatro Calderón in Molina in 1901.<ref>Calero Delso 2013</ref> In the late 1920s and early 1930s he was active in Madrid as amateur actor in cultural associations like [[Sociedad Española de Arte]];<ref>''ABC'' 09.05.28, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1928/05/09/036.html here], ''ABC'' 25.03.31, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1931/03/25/042.htm here] l</ref> he also founded a theatrical group “Nosotros”, based in Casa de Guadalajara in Madrid and active between 1934 and 1938. Finally, Abánades kept delivering public lectures, be it either on history of Molina,<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 12.01.34, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000520322&page=5 here]</ref> on Virgen de la Hoz<ref>''ABC'' 17.06.44, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1944/06/17/017.html here]</ref> or on de Mella and Traditionalist doctrine.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 10.01.36, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000571331&page=2 here]</ref>
==Carlist: ''Restauración''== [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|left|Carlist standard]] In the late 19th century the Guadalajara provincial Carlism lost much of its previous appeal, reduced mostly to support among peasantry.<ref>Calero Delso 2001-2, p. 375</ref> Nothing is known of political preferences of Pedro Abánades Jiménez, though he was allegedly proud of his son’s beginnings of a conservative Catholic publisher.<ref>''La Torre de Aragón'' 15.01.07, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/pdf.raw?query=parent%3A0004276617+type%3Apress%2Fpage&name=La+Torre+de+Arag%C3%B3n.+15-1-1907%2C+no.+5 here]</ref> Apart from journalism, Claro served the cause also as an enthusiastic local Carlist activist; in 1896 he was elected president of [[Juventud Católica]] in Molina<ref>Calero Delso 2013</ref> and co-founded [[La Benéfica Molinesa]], a Catholic social fund.<ref>together with Manuel Gómez de Llerena, Francisco Iturbe, Claudio Josa, Celestino Marco y Pedro Granje. He was its treasurer until 1908, Calero Delso 2013</ref> Thanks to his work Señorio de Molina became the most dynamic Carlist county in the province, though he animated party structures also beyond Castile; he is noted as active in the neighboring [[Teruel Province|Teruel]],<ref>like in 1897, Jordi Canal i Morell, ''Banderas blancas, boinas rojas: una historia política del carlismo, 1876–1939'', Madrid 2006, {{ISBN|8496467341}}, 9788496467347, p. 153</ref> e.g. in 1897 co-organising the propaganda tour of [[Enrique de Aguilera y Gamboa|marquis de Cerralbo]].<ref>Jordi Canal, ''La revitalización política del carlismo a fines del siglo XIX: los viajes de propaganda del Marqués de Cerralbo'', [in:] ''Studia Zamorensia'' 3 (1996), p. 269</ref> Following the death of provincial leader, [[José de Sagarmínaga]], the new one [[Pablo Marín Alonso]] considered Abánades one of the future alcarreña leaders and directed him towards the press propaganda, possibly resulting in launching two periodicals in 1906 and 1908.<ref>Calero Delso 2013</ref>
During a [[Juventud Jaimista]] homage meeting in a Madrid restaurant in 1911 Abánades first met Juan Vazquez de Mella, the encounter which shaped his political future and theoretical outlook for the rest of his life.<ref>many Carlists were present in Madrid, as they came to attend the Congreso Eucaristico, Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''La continuidad ideológica del carlismo tras la Guerra Civil'' [PhD thesis in Historia Contemporanea, Universidad Nacional de Educación a Distancia], Valencia 2009, p. 454</ref> He immediately became one of de Mella’s followers, the faction increasingly at odds with the Carlist claimant. Though during the First World War [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Jaime III]] officially backed neutral stance leaning towards the [[Entente Cordiale|Entente]], in 1915 Abánades together with Manuel Abelló and de Mella published ''El año germanófilo'', dubbed “perfect manual of a germanophile”, and kept delivering pro-German lectures.<ref>“Germany is the most chivalrous nation while Iberia is the Latin race capable of pursuing great objectives and serving all the humanity. Germany was persecuted; it was England trying to snatch away its commerce and industry, as it has done with ours. Today Germany is a giant nation gallantly flying its colors; it keeps fighting the most formidable duel of the centuries. We do not intend to intervene in the struggle of two peoples, taking place in the centre of the world. Longing for peace, we want to establish sympathy between the Spaniards and the Germans; inspired by reasons put forward by our great man, Juan Vazquez de Mella, we want to set up an alliance with Germany to make sure that in the times to come unredeemed territories come back to the Spanish nation”, full text available [https://archive.org/stream/elanogermanofilo00madruoft/elanogermanofilo00madruoft_djvu.txt. here]</ref> It was de Mella who invited him to join ''El Correo Español'', the official party newspaper that two opposing Carlist factions competed to control. Finally, in 1919 Abánades followed de Mella when he was expulsed from the party.<ref>Calero Delso 2013</ref> [[File:Juan Vazquez de Mella 1906.JPG|thumbnail|160px|[[Juan Vazquez de Mella]]]] The years of 1919–1923 mark the climax of Abánades’ political career, as it was the only period when he emerged from the party back benches. Though he did not hold any major posts in the newly emergent Mellist organization, [[:es:Partido Católico Tradicionalista|Partido Tradicionalista]]<ref>he is not listed among provincial party leaders, Juan Ramón de Andrés Martín, ''El cisma mellista. Historia de una ambición política'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|9788487863820}}, p. 197</ref> and by historians he is not counted among key Mellistas,<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 165</ref> he was entrusted with the task of managing the party newspaper, ''El Pensamiento Español''. Abánades propagated political line of his leader, speaking against taking any official posts,<ref>as that would be repeating the liberal crime, Andrés Martín 2000, p. 216</ref> lambasting idea of a right-wing monarchist party<ref>the vision promoted by ''El Debate''; he went on saying that “mejor seía pedir la adhesión de las extremas derechas a un Ministerio o a un soberano efectivo; de ningun modo a quien no lo es”, quoted after Andrés Martín 2000, p. 225</ref> and especially voicing mistrust towards some conciliatory gestures made by [[Alfonso XIII]] versus Traditionalism.<ref>like spiritual subordination of Spain to Jesus in 1919 and criticism of liberal parliamentarism, which allowed ''El Debate'' to recommend Alfonso XIII to the Carlists as “tradicionalista convencido y hasta antiparlamentario”. Abánades responded writing that “antiliberal por el discurso del Cerro de los Angeles, y como antiparlamentario por el de Córdoba; pero como un cautivo del sistema liberal y parlamentario [...] para qué invita a las extremas derechas? Paraque rompan el cautiverio o para qué sean cautivos también”?, Andrés Martín 2000, p. 225</ref> He advocated derogation of [[:es:Constitución española de 1876|1876 constitution]]<ref>“necesario exitrpar también el regimen escrito”, Andrés Martín 2000, p. 226</ref> and building an entirely new Traditionalist regime, possibly based on military dictatorship.<ref>“Debemes seguir el ejemplo de los legitimistas lusitanos”, Andrés Martín 2000, p. 226</ref> At the time when political system of [[Restoration (Spain)|Restauración]] was falling into pieces and two major [[:es:Bipartidismo en España|partidos turnistas]] were rapidly disintegrating, it might have appeared that an anti-establishment extreme-Right alliance envisioned by de Mella could grow into a major player on the Spanish political scene. However, Mellismo proved ineffective as agglutinatory force and decomposed in the early 1920s;<ref>La Asamblea de Zaragoza of October 1922, animated by [[Víctor Pradera Larumbe|Victor Pradera]], delivered a deadly blow to Mellismo, Andrés Martín 2000, pp. 237-241</ref> ''El Pensamiento Español'' ceasing to exist.
==Carlist: dictatorship, republic and Francoism==
Unlike most [[Mellismo|Mellistas]] who left the party to pursue their career elsewhere, Abánades was one of the few faithful and remained also a personal friend of Mella, who withdrew from politics.<ref>''ABC'' 22.12.73, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1973/12/22/049.html here]</ref> This boiled down to his political isolation during [[Miguel Primo de Rivera|Primo de Rivera]] dictatorship; Abánades was active neither in semi-official Carlist structures nor in official primoderiverista institutions. In 1931–1932 together with many already orphaned former Mellistas he reconciled with the new Carlist king [[Alfonso Carlos, Duke of San Jaime|Alfonso Carlos]] and joined the united Carlist organization, [[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista|Comunión Tradicionalista]]. He did not assume major posts, merely forming part of Junta del Círculo Tradicionalista de Madrid.<ref>Calero Delso 2013</ref> His contribution to the cause consisted mostly of propaganda activities: press articles, books, booklets<ref>in 1935 he went on to declare that it is now the time to fulfill the “I will return” promise of [[Carlos, Duke of Madrid|Carlos VII]] of 1876, Canal 2006, p. 48</ref> and semi-scholarly lectures.<ref>he preferred lectures on closed meetings to harangues on public gatherings, for an example see ''ABC'' 02.02.35, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1935/02/02/040.html here]</ref> Second-row speaker, he was usually not mentioned in press headlines.<ref>compare ''El Siglo Futuro'' 27.02.35, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000537220&page=3 here]</ref> His modest personal victory was getting elected to Madrid educational board,<ref>named Junta del Colegio de Doctores y Licenciados en Filosofia y Letras y en Ciencias</ref> hailed by conservative press as “triumph of the Right”.<ref>''ABC'' 17.01.33, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1933/01/17/017.html here]; he was active in the organisation since the mid-1920s, see ''El Imparcial'' 03.02.27, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000995738&page=7 here]</ref>
It is not clear whether Abánades was involved or aware of the forthcoming [[Spanish coup of July 1936|coup of July 1936]]; none of the sources consulted provides also any information about his whereabouts during the Civil War and the very first years of Francoism. A single author claims he joined those Carlists who estranged the intransigent regent-claimant [[Prince Xavier of Bourbon-Parma|Don Javier]] and aligned themselves with the [[:es:Decreto de Unificación|partido unico]] amalgamation line; indeed in 1943 he is noted as paying homage to founders of Falange<ref>''ABC'' 12.03.43, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1943/03/12/009.html here]</ref> and involved in the Francoist propaganda, especially ''El Alcazar''.<ref>Calero Delso 2013, though at least until 1948 he is recorded as contributing to ''El Alcazar'', as he is not mentioned in Rodriguez Virgili 2000</ref> On the other hand, at the same time he was recorded as active in Academia Vazquez de Mella, a semi-official Carlist cultural enterprise;<ref>in 1942 was reported by the press as head of “grupo escolar Vazquez de Mella", ''ABC'' 26.02.43, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1943/02/26/011.html here], active in the group also in 1947, see ''ABC'' 27.02.47, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1947/02/27/011.html here]</ref> In the 1940s he joined supporters of [[Archduke Karl Pius of Austria, Prince of Tuscany|Karl Pius]], styled as the Carlist claimant Carlos VIII,<ref>he is listed as [[Carloctavismo|carloctavist]]a with no specific access date given, Francisco de las Heras y Borreo, ''Un pretendiente desconocido. Carlos de Habsburgo. El otro candidato de Franco, Madrid 2004, {{ISBN|8497725565}}, p. 157</ref> though at that time he was engaged mostly in religious projects, culminating in crowning of Virgen de la Hoz as Reina de Molina de Aragón.<ref>and used to spend part of his summer holidays in Barranco de la Hoz, near the sanctuary, Calero Delso 2013</ref> [[File:Carlos Hugo 1968.jpg|thumbnail|160px|[[Carlos Hugo]], 1968]] Once Carlism abandoned its opposition strategy in the mid-1950s Abánades was awkwardly involved in a new internal power struggle. At that time a young generation of socially minded activists, grouped around [[Carlos Hugo, Duke of Parma|prince Carlos Hugo]], launched their bid to take control of Carlism. It was they who benefitted most from the new rapprochement policy towards Francoism, as javieristas controlled many new Carlist institutions, now officially permitted by the regime. One of them was [[Círculos Culturales Vázquez de Mella]],<ref>the other key structures were a Carlist workers’ organisation Movimiento ObreroTradicionalista (MOT), students’ association Agrupación de Estudiantes Tradicionalistas (AET) and new periodicals, especially ''Azada y asta'' and ''[[Montejurra (magazine)|Montejurra]]''</ref> soon formatted by the socialist youth as means of disseminating their vision.<ref>for details, see Francisco Javier Caspistegui Gorasurreta, ''El naufragio de las ortodoxias. El carlismo, 1962–1977'', Pamplona 1997; {{ISBN|9788431315641}}, 9788431315641 and Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''Carlos Hugo frente a Juan Carlos.: La solución federal para España que Franco rechazó'', Madrid 2014, {{ISBN|9788477682653}}</ref> Not yet ready for open challenge, they invited older Carlists as front-men, supposed to provide them with Traditionalist credentials.<ref>in 1958 Carlos Hugo wrote to him: “La proclamación de las Leyes Fundamentales en mayo 1958 [sic!] es el triunfo definitivo y la gloria de Juan Vázquez de Mella”, Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, p. 10</ref> Abánades was probably not aware of the plot when elected president of Junta Nacional de los Círculos Vázquez de Mella in 1959,<ref>Jordi Canal, ''El carlismo'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|8420639478}}, p. 357</ref> later becoming the honorary president.<ref>he was replaced by Miguel Fagoaga, ''ABC'' 13.11.62, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1962/11/13/059.html here]</ref> In the early 1960s - officially reconciled with the Javierista Carlists<ref>e.g. nominated to preside of Javiersta feasts in 1962, Ramón María Rodon Guinjoan, ''Invierno, primavera y otoño del carlismo (1939-1976)'' [PhD thesis Universitat Abat Oliba CEU], Barcelona 2015, p. 204; in 1962 he co-signed a letter hailing "la feliz consecución de la plena unidad carlista bajo la autoridad de S. M. C. don Javier de Borbón Parma", Heras y Borreo 2004, p. 157</ref> - he was celebrated by Carlos Hugo and his faction, awarded orders,<ref>Orden de la Legitimidad Proscrita</ref> presiding over official homages to de Mella,<ref>''ABC'' 17.06.61, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1961/06/17/058.html here], ''ABC'' 11.10.61, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1961/10/11/049.htm here] l</ref> quoted as authority on his writings<ref>instead of mid-age experts on de Mella, [[Francisco Elías de Tejada y Spínola|Francisco Elias de Tejada]] and [[Rafael Gambra Ciudad|Rafael Gambra]], who firmly pursued the Traditionalist line. When re-creating the Carlist student organisation [[AET (Carlist organisation)|AET]] in the early 1960s, the javieristas kept making constant references to de Mella’s vision of sociedalismo and quoting Abánades, Martorell Perez 2009, p. 466</ref> and receiving flattering letters from the prince.<ref>Carlos Hugo wrote to Abánades, probably consciously expoiting his lifetime adherence to Mella: “Mella no es el canto del pasado. Utiliza el pasado para exponer su sistema (...) La tradición es un conjunto de soluciones que han creado los hombres y que la historia ha acreditado como eficaces (...) La tradición no puede suponer nunca una coacción del pasado; es un proyecto de futuro, a partir de una altura histórica [...] La necesidad origina y precede a la tradición; de ahí que, cuando surgen problemas nuevos, es necesario inventar tradiciones nuevas cara el futuro”, quoted after Martorell Perez 2009, p. 454</ref> In 1969<ref>in 1968 he was still recorded as honorary president, ''ABC'' 28.04.68, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1968/04/28/086.html here]</ref> he published his last article identified, printed in the Carlist periodical.<ref>the piece in question was an analysis of de Mella’s outlook, see ''Portavoz del Circulo Cultural Vazquez de Mella'' September 1969, available [http://ddd.uab.cat/pub/ppc/VM/VM_a1969m8-9n3.pdf here]</ref>

{{Morefootnotes|date=March 2017}} [[File:Eisenhower jacket 88122.jpg|right|thumb|175px|WWII-era Tailor Made Officer's Eisenhower jacket.<ref name="found-nyc1943">http://www.found-nyc.com/blog/2008/01/16/original-design-02-m-1943-field-jacket/</ref>]] [[File:Andersoncoat.jpg|thumb|right|175px|All-purpose service coat.]]
The '''Eisenhower jacket''', or '''"Ike" jacket''', is a type of waist length jacket or [[blouson]] developed for the U.S. Army during the later stages of World War II. Intended to be worn on its own or as an insulating layer beneath the [[U.S. Army M-1943 Uniform|M-43 Field Jacket]],{{citation needed|date=April 2015}} it featured a pleated back, adjustable waist band, fly-front buttons, bellows chest pockets, slash side pockets, and [[Shoulder strap#Military shoulder strap|shoulder straps]].
==Overview== Until the late-1930s, the [[United States Army]]’s field uniform consisted of a [[wool]] [[shirt]], mid-hip-length "all-purpose service coat" and wool overcoat. Save for its belted waist, the single-breasted service coat resembled a [[suit (clothing)|suit]] or [[sport coat]] more than a uniform. Little changed since World War I, it featured notched lapels and five metal buttons from its open collar to its belted waist. Made of heavy wool [[Serge (fabric)|serge]], it touted two flapped and button-through patch pockets at the breast and two identically styled patch pockets below its belted waist – its four pockets either box-pleated or bellows-styled-pleats.<ref>{{cite book|author=Philip Katcher|year=1978|title=The US Army 1941-45|publisher=Ospery Publishing Ltd|ISBN=0-85045-522-7}}</ref>
Using [[civilian]] "[[windbreaker]]s" as its ideal design objective, the army began a four-year study in 1935 to develop a more practical and effective combat jacket to replace the service coat.
[[File:M1941 Jacket.jpg|thumb|right|175px|M-41 Field Jacket or "Parsons' Jacket".<ref name="found-nyc1943"/>]]
In 1940, it first adopted the first pattern field jacket, the "Parsons Jacket" named for Major General [[James K. Parsons]] who helped with its development. This was quickly followed by an updated pattern, using the same nomenclature. Simply designed and modeled after a civilian [[windbreaker]] made by John Rissman & Sons of Chicago, it was a short, button-front [[weatherproof]] [[jacket]] with a tight fitting waist and two flapped and button-through front pockets.
In early 1943, front-line [[skirmishes]] in [[North Africa]] and [[Europe]] proved the Service Coat, as well as the field jacket, inappropriate for combat. The Service Coat was re-designated for [[garrison]] and parade duty and the field jacket was replaced by a new and completely redesigned Field Jacket, M-1943.<ref>{{cite book|author=William Emerson|year=1996|title=Encyclopedia of United States Army Insignia and Uniforms|publisher=The University of Oklahoma Press, Norman, Publishing Division of the University|ISBN=0-8061-2622-1}}</ref>
==Field Jacket, O.D. ("Parsons Jacket")== Although the Field Jacket, O.D. (more widely known as the "Parsons Jacket" or the modern term "M41 Jacket") was widely used in many theaters during World War II, it was found to be an unsatisfactory solution for the soldiers using it. The War Department created a new field jacket based on the layering principle to give greater flexibility for the numerous environmental conditions encountered in the world-wide war.<ref name="found-nyc1943"/>
==Field Jacket, M-1943== {{details|U.S. Army M-1943 Uniform}} [[File:M1943 Field Jacket.jpg|right|thumb|175px|M-43 Field Jacket.<ref name="found-nyc1943"/>]] Built around the [[layered clothing|layering]] principle, the [[U.S. Army M-1943 Uniform|M-1943]] became the basic building block of a multi-environment, all-season [[combat]] uniform being developed by the Office of the Quartermaster General (OQMG) for worldwide combat.<ref name="found-nyc1943"/>
On May 15, 1943, the [[Air Transport Command (United States Air Force)|Air Transport Command]] (ATC) recommended development of a short, waist cropped woolen field jacket that could be worn under the M-1943 as an added [[Thermal insulation|insulator]].
==Field Jackets, Wool, O.D.== By mid-1944, the OQMG finalized the several layering components of its multi-environment combat uniform, anointing the M-1943 Field Jacket its basic, universal building block. A completely new design, the M-1943 touted a wind-proof, olive drab colored [[cotton]] [[poplin]] outer shell with internal layers that could be added or eliminated depending on local battle conditions. In cold [[wikt:environ|environ]]s, its notched lapels converted to a stand-up, storm-flap for added neck protections. A pile jacket [[wikt:Special:Search/liner|liner]] and fur-edged hood could also be added.<ref name="found-nyc1943"/>
During the Autumn of 1943, the [[United States Army Air Corps|Army Air Corps]] prototype jacket was sent to Chief Quartermaster of the [[European Theater of Operations]] for review and possible adoption by ETO commanding general, [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]].
==The Eisenhower Jacket== [[File:Allied_Commanders_after_Germany_Surrendered.jpg|thumb|Eisenhower, wearing his M44 jacket, with some Allied commanders following the signing of the German Instrument of Surrender at Reims.]] Eisenhower had already requested a waist-cropped style; stemming from his appreciation of the functionality of the British [[Battle Dress|battle jacket]], "but with more distinctive style."{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}
The M-44 jacket that emerged was fundamentally a waist-length M-43, with some improvements. Made of olive drab 18-ounce wool [[Serge (fabric)|serge]], it shared the notched [[Jacket lapel|lapel]] "storm collar", snag-free "fly front" buttons and flapped, bellows breast pockets, shoulder straps for gear retention, and roomy sleeves to accommodate insulating layers.<ref>{{cite book|author=Shelby Stanton|year=1991|title=U.S. Army Uniforms of WWII|publisher=Stackpole Books|ISBN=0-8117-2595-2}}</ref>
Staggered cuff buttons adjusted for layering or allowed a loose fit in warmer conditions, as did adjustable waist buckles. A pair of "action-back" pleats extended from shoulder to waistband, providing freedom of movement with a slim fit. Intended to be worn on its own or underneath the M-43,{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}, the "Ike jacket", was classified standard issue in November 1944, and additionally designated as the Army’s dress and parade uniform.{{citation needed|date=April 2015}}
According to [[Paul Fussell]]’s Uniforms, "Eisenhower had a reputation among his troops as an eminently decent man, friendly and sympathetic," an admiration that Ike elevated even further, tells Fussell, by having the bravado to casually rest his hands inside his pocket and "violate the sacred Army injunction." That anecdote, Fussell says, explains why Eisenhower refused to adorn his personal jacket with gilded buttons: He considered his jacket an every-warrior’s combat uniform.<ref>{{cite book|page=42|author=Paul Fussell|title=Uniforms: Why We Are What We Wear|publisher=Houghton Mifflin|year=2003|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lERXgU9uQS4C | isbn=978-0-618-38188-3}}</ref> Eisenhower died in 1969 and was buried dressed in his famous short green jacket.<ref name=FinalPost>{{cite web|accessdate=August 21, 2012|url=https://www.eisenhower.archives.gov/all_about_ike/final_post.html|title=Dwight D. Eisenhower – Final Post|publisher=[[Eisenhower Presidential Center]]}}</ref>
==The US Marine Corps and the Vandegrift jacket== Following the [[Guadalcanal Campaign]], the [[1st Marine Division (United States)|1st Marine Division]] under Major General [[Alexander Vandegrift]] were posted to the cooler climate of [[Melbourne]] Australia. As the Marines only had dungarees and tan summer uniforms, they were issued Australian army [[battle dress]] with the Marines calling the short jacket the '''''Vandegrift Jacket'''''. An American made forest green version was issued to officers in December 1944 and to enlisted Marines in August 1945.<ref>p.31 Rottman, Gordon L. ''US Marine Corps 1941-45'' Osprey Publishing, 15/05/1995</ref> The Vandegrift jacket was retained until 1960.
==The post-WWII redesigns and adaptations== [[File:Michael Fisher.jpg|thumb|right|175px|Chief of the U.S. Border Patrol [[Michael J. Fisher]] wearing the [[U.S. Border Patrol|Border Patrol's]] version of the Ike Jacket.]]
Post-World War II development of the U.S. field jacket was momentous. In 1947, the Army introduced a shorter and better tailored version of the M-44. Designated the MQ-1 and designed solely as a [[Dress uniform|dress and parade uniform]], the jacket was again refined in 1950 and re-introduced as the M-1950 Field Jacket, but without button cuffs. With the later introduction of the "Army green" [[U.S. Army service uniform#Green Service Uniform|U.S. Army service uniform]] in 1957, the Ike jacket gradually began to disappear domestically but was still a uniform option for troops stationed in international theaters.
In 1947, the [[United States Air Force]] (USAF) added still another Ike jacket design iteration, the M-47, and continued its use for the next two years, before changing its color to "[[Air Force blue]]" in 1949, where it remained a signature of the USAF, until being retired in 1964.<ref>[http://usafflagranks.com/usaf_service_dress_ike_jacket.html United States Air Force Dress Ike Jacket]</ref>
The design of the M-1943 jacket was to prove so successful that many military forces around the world still wear field jackets that closely follow its original designs. During the 1950s, a modified version, called the M-1950, was issued to U.S. forces in [[Korea]]. It had a button-in liner instead of the separate liner garment as in the M-1943. During the next year, the sometimes permanently hooded, M-1951 coat came into use. It was another very similar design, but now had both a zip instead of buttons under the front fly and metal snap closures for the pockets. The [[M-1951 field jacket]] was actually not sent to the forces in Korea until after the 1953 armistice and so was not seen during the [[Korean War]]. It thus remained in service until replaced by the [[M-1965 field jacket]] in 1965.<ref name="found-nyc1943"/>
Thanks to its greater comfort and the unobstructed ease it offered while operating a vehicle or brandishing a side-arm, the Ike jacket design became a popular post-WWII uniform staple among Federal and state law enforcement agencies as well as with countless numbers of municipal and civilian police departments throughout America.
To this day, uniforms of the [[U.S. Border Patrol]], along with most allied agencies within its broader, umbrella department, the [[U.S. Customs and Border Protection]] Agency (USCBPA) and the [[National Park Service]] (NPS) have a dress jacket that is nearly identical to the Ike jacket original.

'''Emilio Comba''' (1839–1904) was a celebrated [[Waldensian]] pastor and historian.<ref>Koenig D. ''Francesco Modon: Colporteur and Evangelist at Rome, 1870'' 1966</ref><ref>Giovanni Gonnet ''Chanforan e la storiografia Valdese (Da [[Scipione Lentolo]] a Ernesto Comba, 1542-1932)'' 1984</ref>
==Works== * 1880 ''Storia dei Valdesi avanti la Reforma'' * 1885 ''Un sinodo anabattista a Venezia anno 1550'' * 1897 ''I Nostri Protestanti'' - 2 volumes
==His son, Ernesto Comba== In 1922 the Waldensian school was transferred from Florence to Rome with Emilio's son [[Teofilo Ernesto Comba]] as professor of the theological faculty.<ref>[http://www.adventistaffirm.org/v15n1/03.print.html ]</ref> * 1923 ''Storia dei Valdesi'' [[Torre Pellice]] * 1927 ''De Waldenzen, hun Oorsprong en Geschiedenis'' [[Kampen, Overijssel|Kampen]], J. H. Kok. Ernesto Comba presented arguments to demonstrate that the name Waldenses derived from valley ("vallis densa" valdensis) and that they already existed before the time of [[Peter Waldo]].

'''George Cockburn Henderson''' (1 May 1870 – c. 9 April 1944) was an Australian academic with a considerable career in Adelaide.
==History== Cockburn was born in [[Hamilton, New South Wales]], the eighth of nine children<ref name=adb/> of Richard T. Henderson (c. 1830–1897) and was educated at Hamilton and [[Lawrence, New South Wales|Lawrence]] public schools. He passed the public instruction examination at age 13 and was admitted to Macquarie Superior Public School as a pupil teacher under his brother Richard Henderson. In December 1889 he won a £72 ''per annum'' scholarship to the [[Fort Street Training College]]. He matriculated the following March and in so doing won two-years' free tuition at Sydney University, later extended by another year.<ref name=Hamiltonian>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article132785681 |title=A Distinguished Hamiltonian |newspaper=[[Newcastle Morning Herald And Miners' Advocate]] |issue=7613 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=5 April 1899 |accessdate=2 July 2018 |page=6 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
He graduated BA in March 1893, winning a gold medal in philosophy, the Fraser Scholarship in History, and the [[James King of Irrawang]] Travelling Scholarship of £110 for two years, and in 1894 he enrolled at [[Balliol College]], Oxford, where he was awarded a [[Brackenbury Scholarship]] in history which funded his studies there to the value of £80 ''per annum'' for five years. He also excelled at athletics and was a leading oarsman and member of the Balliol crew at the Henley and Oxford races.<ref name=Henderson/> He graduated MA and was employed in various parts of England as a [[University extension]] lecturer.<ref name=death>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article48791944 |title=Death of Prof. G.C. Henderson |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)]] |location=South Australia |date=10 April 1944 |accessdate=2 July 2018 |page=4 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> In recognition of his highly successful work, he was promoted by the Oxford extension delegacy to first-class lecturer.<ref name=Henderson>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71325403 |title=Mr. G. C. Henderson, B.A. |newspaper=[[Australian Town And Country Journal]] |volume=LVIII, |issue=1519 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=18 March 1899 |accessdate=2 July 2018 |page=24 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
In 1898 he accepted a position at Sydney University as Acting Professor of History, while [[George Arnold Wood|Professor Wood]] was on holiday in England. On 5 January 1899, two days before leaving, he married May Gertrude Sturge, a niece of [[John Bright]] and of [[Joseph Sturge]],<ref name=Hamiltonian/> at the Friends' Meeting Place, [[Leicester]], England. They arrived in Sydney aboard the P & O steamer ''Oceana'' in late February.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article113701835 |title=An Australian Scholar Returned |newspaper=[[The Evening News (Sydney)]] |issue=9901 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=1 March 1899 |accessdate=2 July 2018 |page=4 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> A second acting Professorship, of Philosophy, arose at Sydney University, which Henderson filled, in 1900 returning to England, living at [[Kingham]], and at [[Charlbury]], in Oxfordshire, the home of his wife's parents.<ref name=courts>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article59088907 |title=In the Courts |newspaper=[[The Register (Adelaide)]] |volume=LXXVI, |issue=20,106 |location=South Australia |date=21 April 1911 |accessdate=2 July 2018 |page=9 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
Early in 1902 Henderson was invited to give a course of lectures in Sydney, and while he was in Australia [[Robert Langton Douglas|Professor Douglas]] peremptorily resigned, and the University of Adelaide offered him the chair of History (or perhaps his friend [[William Mitchell (philosopher)|William Mitchell]], professor of English and Philosophy, persuaded him to apply); he accepted and took up residence in North Adelaide. He attempted to persuade his wife to join him, but she repeatedly declined. By 1910 she was living with one Richard Henry Gretton, and Henderson instituted divorce proceedings.<ref name=courts/> Henderson was spending much of his spare time at the [[Adelaide Club]].<ref name=adb/>
In 1921 [[Charles Rischbieth Jury|Mrs G. A. Jury]] made a bequest to the University, which enabled Henderson's dual responsibilities to be divided: [[A. T. Strong]] was appointed to the Jury professorship of English Literature in 1922, and Henderson retained the Professorship of Modern History. On 27 October 1922 Henderson married Dr. [[Annie Heloise Abel]] (1873–1947), an English-born Professor of History in America, with an interest in American colonial history.<ref name=death/> They settled on a rural property at [[Blackwood, South Australia|Blackwood]], but she was unhappy; he suffered a nervous breakdown and was hospitalised in June 1923 and insisted she leave him; they divorced on the grounds of incompatibility.<ref>{{cite book|title=Notable American Women, 1607–1950: A Biographical Dictionary, Volume 1: Abel|publisher=[[Radcliffe College]]|page=5}}</ref> Henderson's resignation from the University was accepted reluctantly and he was awarded the title of [[Professor Emeritus]].<ref name=adb/>
He moved to [[Dora Creek, New South Wales]] in 1923.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article164839223 |title=People in the News |newspaper=[[The Observer (Adelaide)]] |volume=LXXX, |issue=5,996 |location=South Australia |date=29 December 1923 |accessdate=3 July 2018 |page=38 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> He continued his historical researches; notably on [[Abel Tasman]] with M. Wieder, the Dutch historian.
He was cared for over the course of 20 years by his niece Elsie Henderson, who lived next door to his "cozy villa". When the pair visited England in 1936 he arranged for Elsie to be presented to the court of [[King Edward VIII]] (later Duke of Windsor).<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article230294718 |title=Attended Reception Given By The King |newspaper=[[The Sun (Sydney)]] |issue=8298 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=7 August 1936 |accessdate=4 July 2018 |page=19 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> It was she who found him on 9 April 1944 near the road on his property, throat slit, with a [[straight razor|razor]] under his body.<ref name=Truth>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article203753401 |title=Professor Suicides: 'My Book Is Finished' |newspaper=[[Truth (Brisbane newspaper)]] |issue=2299 |location=Queensland, Australia |date=16 April 1944 |accessdate=3 July 2018 |page=23 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
==Other activities== *He represented the University on the Board of Governors of the Public Library. Art Gallery, and Museum *He was Chairman of the library committee and the archives department, which opened in 1920,<ref name=adb>G. L. Fischer, 'Henderson, George Cockburn (1870–1944)', Australian Dictionary of Biography, National Centre of Biography, Australian National University, http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/henderson-george-cockburn-6630/text11421, published first in hardcopy 1983, accessed online 3 July 2018.</ref> and owed much of its early success to his insistence that wherever possible archive material should be donated rather than purchased. *He gave a large number of public lectures in Adelaide, and in [[Perth]] May–June 1906, 1907 and 1908, to packed and appreciative houses.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article37399580 |title=Professor Henderson's Lectures |newspaper=[[Western Mail (Western Australia)|Western Mail]] |volume=XXII, |issue=1,119 |location=Western Australia |date=8 June 1907 |accessdate=3 July 2018 |page=21 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> He was a powerful advocate for establishment of a university in Western Australia. *He was a supporter of the Literary Societies movement and the [[South Australian Literary Societies' Union]], of which he was president in 1906.
==Publications== *Henderson, G. C. ''Sir George Grey; Pioneer of Empire in Southern Lands'' Dent & Co., of London (1907) *Henderson, G. C. ''Fiji and the Fijians 1835–1856''' *Henderson, G. C., Thomas Williams ''The journal of Thomas Williams, missionary in Fiji, 1840-1853, Volume 1'' Angus & Robertson (1931) *Henderson, G. C. ''The discoverers of the Fiji Islands: Tasman, Cook, Bligh, Wilson, Bellinghausen'' J. Murray, (1933)
==Recognition== *He left the bulk of his estate to the University of Sydney to fund the G. C. Henderson research scholarship, studying the South Pacific islands. *The Henderson room at the History Department at the University of Adelaide, which carries much of his library, was named for him.<ref name=adb/>
==Further reading== *''George Cockburn Henderson – a Memoir'' Libraries Board of South Australia (1964) by Marjory R. Casson *''A History of the Faculty of Arts at the University of Adelaide 1876-2012'' ed. Nick Harvey ''et al.'' *{{cite web|author=G. L. Fischer|title=Henderson, George Cockburn (1870–1944)|publisher=Australian Dictionary of Biography, National Centre of Biography, Australian National University|url=http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/henderson-george-cockburn-6630/text11421|access-date=3 July 2018}}

The '''Glasgow Chronology''' is a proposed revision of the [[Egyptian chronology]] of [[ancient Egypt]]. It was first formulated between the years 1978 and 1982 by a working group following the Glasgow Conference of Society for Interdisciplinary Studies (SIS, a non-profit organization advocating serious academic analysis of the writings of [[Immanuel Velikovsky]] and other [[catastrophism|catastrophist]]s).<ref name=Sweeney>{{cite book|title=Empire of Thebes, or, Ages in chaos revisited|author=Emmet John Sweeney|pages=19|publisher=Algora Publishing|year=2007| isbn=9780875864808 }}</ref>
This [[chronology]] placed the [[Eighteenth dynasty of Egypt]] some five hundred years later than the [[conventional chronology of Egypt]].
==Chronology formation== The Glasgow Chronology was initially presented at an SIS conference, held in 1978 in [[Glasgow]] and entitled "Ages in Chaos?". Flaws were pointed out in it almost immediately, and by the 1980s its original proponents had all abandoned it, in favour of other chronologies.<ref name=Sweeney />
The Glasgow Chronology accepted all the character identifications proposed by [[Velikovsky]] in ''[[Ages in Chaos]]'' (1952). Thus [[Hatshepsut]], who visited the Divine Land, was equated with the [[Queen of Sheba]], who visited [[Solomon]] in [[Jerusalem]], whilst [[Thutmose III]], who followed Hatshepsut, was equated with [[Shishak]], who plundered the Jerusalem temple after the death of Solomon. Velikovsky therefore reduced the age of the [[Eighteenth Dynasty]] by five centuries. However, in his subsequently published ''Ramses II and his Time'' (1978), he brought the Nineteenth dynasty down by roughly seven centuries, thus opening a two-century gap between the Eighteenth and Nineteenth dynasties. Despite the Glasgow Chronology intent of reducing the age of the Nineteenth dynasty by five centuries and allowing it to naturally follow from the Eighteenth dynasty, its original proponents concluded that it was historically insupportable.
==See also== *[[Phantom time hypothesis]]

The '''Great Contract''' was a plan submitted to [[James I of England|James I]] and [[Parliament of England|Parliament]] in 1610 by [[Robert Cecil, 1st Earl of Salisbury|Robert Cecil]]. It was an attempt to increase Crown income and ultimately rid it of debt.
Cecil suggested that, in return for an annual grant of £200,000, the Crown should give up its [[feudal]] rights of [[Ward (law)|Wardship]] and [[Purveyance]], as well as [[New Impositions]]. The plan was eventually rejected by both James and Parliament: the failure of his cherished project was thought by some to have hastened Cecil's early death in 1612, although it is most likely that he died of [[cancer]]. The King withdrew from the contract because it meant that he would lose a useful means of controlling his more powerful subjects, and he also did not think £200,000 was a worthy substitute for his feudal rights. The House of Commons withdrew because they were wary of providing an income that might give the King financial independence.
Whether it would have helped the financial situation remains a matter of speculation. It has been argued that the financial settlement at the [[Restoration of Charles II]] was partly inspired by the Great Contract. On the other hand, James I was rather extravagant in financial matters, and it is uncertain whether the Contract would have been a permanent solution of his difficulties. It is also important to consider how, at the point of Elizabeth's death, the Crown was £400,000 in debt, considering that Elizabeth ran a rather frugal court and was careful with money, and thus the financial problems of James' reign were not all of his own making. Furthermore, it must also be said that James, who had a wife and, by 1605, four children to support, had many legitimate expenses which the unmarried and childless Elizabeth did not.
==See also== *[[Tenures Abolition Act 1660]]
==References== *Kenyon, J.P. ''The Stuarts'' Fontana edition 1966

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Use Irish English|date=July 2015}} The '''Green Street Trust''' was an Irish company incorporated in 1990 with charitable status. Its aim was to promote urban renewal in disadvantaged inner city areas through the rehabilitation of historic buildings for contemporary use and where possible to secure multiple uses within individual buildings. The Trust obtained a 99 year lease from the [[Office of Public Works]] (OPW) of the former [[Debtors' Prison Dublin|Debtors’ Prison]] situated on Halston Street and Green Street in Dublin’s north inner city and undertook restoration works to the building to plans prepared by McCullough Mulvin Architects.<ref>Sunday Business Post 'Locked away for the public good' Teri Griffin, 5 November 1995</ref><ref>Irish Times ‘Plans to convert former Debtors Prison into flats’, 5 December 1991</ref>
In August 1992 a group of volunteers from Voluntary Service International carried out restoration works to the building.<ref>Irish Times ‘Debtors’ Prison makes welcome return’ 19 August 1992</ref> In 1994 the Trust ran a carpentry and joinery course as a Fás Community Youth Training Project to replace the timber sash windows in the building that were in poor condition. The Trust carried out substantial works to refurbish the Debtors’ Prison in the 1990s but due to escalating building costs and a lack of funding construction work ceased and the Trust handed back the lease to the OPW.
Most of its directors of the company had been members of [[Students Against the Destruction of Dublin]].<ref>Sunday Business Post 'Locked away for the public good' Teri Griffin, 5 November 1995</ref> The directors included [[Tony Connelly]], Frank Cooney, [[Ciarán Cuffe]], Deryck Fay (Company Secretary), Emma Kelly, Garret Kelly, Ger Lambert, Richard Lyons, Eunan McLaughlin, Rachel McRory (Chair), Colm Murray, Jerome Ó Drisceoil, Colmán Ó Siochrú, and Blaise Smith.
Its patrons were Dermot Egan, The [[Knight of Glin]], Justice [[Niall McCarthy (judge)|Niall McCarthy]], [https://www.tcd.ie/chancellor/prochancellor/current/mcparland.php Dr. Edward McParland], John O’Connor, Breege O’Donaghue, [[Ruairi Quinn|Ruairí Quinn TD]], [[Nicholas Robinson (historian)|Nicholas Robinson]], Gerry Walker and [http://www.museum.ie/en/news/press-releases.aspx?article=e9bbcd83-9967-4c3e-8620-158f9fbb1e51 Dr. Pat Wallace].
